Second, that children are not taught that they are oppressors or oppressed but are taught to respect everyone around them regardless of external factors. Third, that schools and educators have adequate resources.

The border would be my highest legislative priority for funding and expanding our human trafficking task force would not be far behind. Also, I think it is appropriate to use the “rainy day fund” for items such as the wall that is a one-time expense used to address situations of incredibly high importance such as border security.
I’ve had a 30 year career as an engineer, project lead and team manager in high-technology firms, large and small. I’ve also been a Republican volunteer and leader here in central Texas for decades.

Texas needs and voters deserve a well established democratic process of free, fair and secure elections. I will fight to make sure that every Texan has confidence in our system, by working to maintain and strengthen our election election integrity laws. I support voter ID requirements, protections against mail in ballot fraud, and strengthened penalties against illegal voting, etc.

I support rights of medical choice, and so oppose socialist healthcare schemes and vaccine mandates that deny freedom of medical choice, and I support access to contraceptives. The pre-born in the womb are living human beings and we have a responsibility to protect their right to life. I am pro-life. We provide Govt support for those in need via Medicaid, clinics, etc.; I support continuing that.

Empower parents: All Texas parents have a right to be informed and empowered to make decisions in all matters regarding their children’s education.
Focus on core learning needs: Covid has left many kids behind, with basic reading and math scores falling; refocus K-12 on basic learning to catch up.
Oppose CRT and leftist indoctrination in K-12: Restore patriotic civics to our classrooms.

I am a fiscal conservative. My priority will be to ensure we keep spending within limits, so we can dedicate Texas revenue surpluses to property tax relief. I want to dedicate our state-level Texas revenue surplus to buy down the M&O tax rate, reducing the property tax burden on Texas homeowners and taxpayers from our local schools.
Dedicated public servant with over a decade in law and public policy, including three years for State Senator Charles Schwertner. Prior to law school, I managed my family’s trucking business.

Voters deserve to have confidence in our elections, and all eligible voters should have the opportunity to cast their ballots. That’s why I support recent legislative efforts to make it easier to vote through expanded early voting hours, while making it harder to cheat. As a Hispanic, I reject claims that election integrity is designed to disenfranchise minority voters.

My wife and I suffered six heartbreaking miscarriages before the birth of our daughter. I know what an immeasurable blessing life is, which is why I’m pro-life until natural death. It’s also why I’m dedicated to protecting vulnerable children in our foster care system, children with special needs, and our parents and grandparents trying to live out their final years in peace and comfort.

As the father of a second grader in Round Rock ISD, I view things from a parent’s perspective and share your frustrations with the COVID learning environment. If elected, I will fight to ensure our schools are preparing the next generation of Texans for success. I believe our schools should focus on education and address COVID related learning loss, not promote political propaganda like CRT.

Securing our border and returning money to the taxpayer to buydown property taxes. I am a proud Hispanic Republican who will fight to secure the border with walls, physical barriers, and increased law enforcement. A local homeowner since 2013, I know property taxes are unsustainable and will work to deliver real property tax relief to keep Texas families from being taxed out of their homes.

races.description: 2-year term. The House is one of two chambers that make up the Texas legislature. The representative is one of 150 representatives. They make and vote on laws, decide where the money goes within the state government, serve on committees such as agriculture and livestock, business and industry, elections, higher education, energy resources, etc. Bills for raising money must originate in the house. Only the house can impeach a statewide officer.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
How would you ensure election laws provide all eligible voters with equal access to safe and fair elections?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health impacts for those who don’t have access to the health services they need?
What are your top priorities for public education?
What is your highest legislative priority for funding, and would you be willing to use Texas’s “rainy day fund” to finance it?

positions.position: I have spent the last several years lobbying at the local, state and national level for autism research, individual liberties, parental rights, and improved public education.

Election integrity is fundamental to ensuring a representative democracy, and those who seek to undermine election security on a broad scale should be subject to criminal penalties. I support the legislation passed in the 87th session that expanded polling hours, strengthened ID requirements and provided uniformity in polling locations, but I would have created a felony for large-scale fraud.

Every consenting adult has the right to prevent conception in whichever way they deem fit. Once fertilization has occurred, that fetus has equal rights under the law and that life should be protected. Access to and education about nutrition and physical fitness would go a long way toward preventing chronic health conditions that disproportionately impact under-served communities.

My top priority in public education is improving and simplifying TEKS by removing mental health and social/emotional learning requirements, allowing ISDs to focus on reading, writing, math, science, and history. I would also vote to eliminate or overhaul state standardized testing, to help create a less stressful environment for students, teachers, and administrators.

All state funding should undergo an audit to ensure that taxpayer money is being spent wisely and efficiently, and that agency activities are benefiting the state. “Rainy day fund” spending is rightfully restrained by the Texas Constitution, so no matter how much of a priority any legislation may be for me, I would not be willing to violate these restraints to fund it.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I am the only candidate Board Certified in Criminal Law by the Texas Board of Legal Specialization. I have served as an assistant district attorney since graduating Magna Cum Laude in December 2011.

I have served my Country as a United States Marine Officer through multiple combat deployments. I have tried numerous felony cases to juries and district court judges. I have passed the rigorous examination and background check to become Board Certified. My life experiences prepared me to be highly competent, proficient, and fair when applying the law to individual cases.

District Judges have a direct role in the safety of the community and the smooth functioning of everyday life. They directly affect public safety during the administration of the criminal justice system, and they keep social tensions at ease with the dispassionate adjudication of civil disputes. Judge Kennon has an extremely well functioning Court, and I seek only to try to fill his shoes.

Common courtesy and a good attitude. Lawyers and clients in court deserve a courteous judge who will fully listen to the problem presented, make a timely ruling based on the law, and deliver a decision without talking down or lecturing the litigants. This means lots of extra time in the courtroom due to case backlog, and lots of late nights reading pleadings to be prepared for said hearings.

Jury trials should be prioritized to deal with the COVID backlog. We have real data now for how the lack of jury trials affects the clearance rate of all cases. Again, lawyers come to court because of disputes, both criminal and civil, and the need for decisions in those disputes. Dockets have languished because of the lack of juries, and all efforts should be focused to that end.

Associate Judge for 3 yrs, Prosecutor for 13 yrs, Graduate of University of Texas 1997 and South TX College of Law, and Fellow in Texas Bar Foundation, honor given only to top 1/3 of 1% of all lawyers

Integrity is the most critical attribute for a judge to possess. Having integrity means, among other things, remaining impartial and removing any personal bias from all judicial proceeding. As a judge, I have never lost sight of the profound impact my decisions have on those who come into my court. I have always been and will continue to be fair and impartial.

The judicial system is a vital safeguard to our community. The court is important to all in the county because matters such as property rights, child custody, and criminal cases are handled in this court. It is essential that a judge have a thorough understanding of the law and apply the law to each case as the law is written. Community safety is of utmost importance to all in our community.

The words “Equal Justice Under Law” have always been a guiding principle during my career. Equal access to justice is a fundamental right. The law is meant to protect all equally without regard to background or financial means. Judges must safeguard that each and every person with a case in the court has equal access to justice by ensuring that indigent defendants are provided competent counsel.

Due to the pandemic, there is a backlog of cases. These cases must be resolved in a fair, efficient manner. Many new procedures must be put into place, including an aggressive trial docket in which multiple cases are set for trial every trial week, establishing a case management schedule, utilizing technology to improve efficiency, and increasing the number of court days each week.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I have 19 years of experience in criminal and civil law, served on several boards in the community, and am committed to Williamson County. In 2020, I was awarded the Judicial Service Award by MADD.

Judges should strictly uphold the rule of law as written and not use the bench to further a personal or political agenda. In addition, it is important that a judge have the right judicial demeanor or temperament so that all parties that come before them are treated with respect, fairly, and given an opportunity to be heard.

Williamson County Court at Law #2 is very important because it not only handles criminal and civil cases, but has a Veterans Treatment Court and misdemeanor DWI/Drug Court program. There is an enormous amount of administrative work that goes into handling the specialty courts as there are four grants to manage. I plan on bringing in more resources and expediating the process for our courts.

I have been and am committed to ensuring that every defendant has effective representation. To that end, court appointed attorney’s performance is monitored regularly and corrective action is taken, if necessary. All parties, to include self-represented litigants, are treated with respect and allowed to be heard. Dockets are monitored closely and decisions are handed down in a timely manner.

The greatest challenge all courts are facing now is a backlog of cases and jury trials from COVID-19. We began addressing this problem immediately by starting virtual dockets and then switching back to in-person dockets in June of 2021. In 2021, we resumed jury trials and numerous cases have been resolved. In addition, I have added additional jury trial dockets in 2022 to get more cases tried.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What are the top three countywide issues you would like to address over your next term, should you be elected?
How will you ensure purposeful growth and development to improve living and business conditions in the county?
How will you improve affordability and reduce the number of people who are unhoused?
How will you address current and future transportation needs in the county?

positions.position: I have 20 years of experience in leading many departments challenged with explosive growth, successfully managing teams from diversified backgrounds & cultures to achieve organizational goals.

Election Integrity. Restore voter confidence Protection of Constitutional Liberties. Freedom to work and worship shall not be infringed upon. We cannot allow forced vaccines, shutdowns etc. to occur in our county. Property Rights and Taxes: Explosive growth requires careful consideration so current property owners are properly compensated in the event the county requires their land.

I will insure our Sherriff’s and Precinct Constables are competitively compensated and funded with necessary equipment to properly serve the public and promote a safe environment to the citizens and business owners of this county. Tax rates lowered to promote growth and reduced cost of living.

Tax rates upon our citizens of Williamson County must be reduced, no increases. I would promote performing lean activities within our county departments aiming to reduce costs. I will work with faith based and non-profit organizations to see how we can support them and work together to help limit homelessness in our county.

Williamson County is one of the fastest growing counties in the United States. I will support proactive requirements to meet capacity needs however I do believe we need to review Williamson County’s process for imminent domain to insure property owners are not unfairly taken advantage of during this historic growth period.
In 2016, Judge Gravell was chosen to be 1 of 24 county elected officials to attend the Texas Association of Counties leadership school. In 2017 He was selected as Judge of the Year in Texas.

1. He has provided law enforcement with the resources, training they need to keep Williamson County families safe. He will oppose any radical efforts to defund the police.
2. He is committed to lowering property taxes and led the charge to raise the homestead exemption for seniors in Williamson County.
3. He has led the charge to bring new jobs and new economic opportunity to Williamson County.

You improve living and business conditions by attracting the right type of business growth. Williamson County has becoming the technology superhighway of the world, stretching from the Apple Inc. in Northwest Austin at the edge of Round Rock to the Dell Technologies Inc. campus in Round Rock to the Samsung site in Taylor, and whatever comes in between.

You address affordable housing by attracting large companies to offset the tax burden on our local citizens. In Williamson County we increase property tax exemptions, providing tax relief to all residential homesteads in the county. Property tax exemptions for persons 65 and older increased from $30,000 to $90,000. Property tax exemption for disabled persons increased from $20,000 to $75,000.
Judge Gravell believes Williamson County is the gold standard for transportation planning and will continue with that mindset in the years to come.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What are the top three countywide issues you would like to address over your next term, should you be elected?
How will you ensure purposeful growth and development to improve living and business conditions in the county?
How will you improve affordability and reduce the number of people who are unhoused?
How will you address current and future transportation needs in the county?

positions.position: Number 1, I’m a citizen, who drives on the worst roads of Williamson Co. Precinct 2. By owning my own construction company, I have the hands on expertise of road construction and crew running.

1. County roads repaired all 4 years, not just the year of election.
2. Be transparent with the people on any new road projects.
3. Developers build into infrastructure a way to put clean water into our waterways.

By causing developers to build the proper types of drainage that drains into our waterways. Encouraging tax rebates for rain water collection. Utilizing the current CR Right of Ways for road expansion, instead of ramming down the throats of citizens unwanted IH type highways, basically taking land from those that have worked hard and built dreams. And, put better thought into tax abatement’s.

Old school, get a job and save towards acquiring your dream. Every person in this country has the same opportunity, if applied. Giving something to someone, free of charge, does not encourage a pride in ownership. We can have low cost rent, but only if people will step up. Just handing something out, doesn’t work. Everyone is born with opportunity. It must be utilized.

Again, by building and expanding on current county owned right of ways. There are plenty of arteries within this county that can, and must be utilized, before the taking of land to build roads to nowhere. Developers will have to join in to building the proper roads in and out of subdivisions. It should not be on the backs of taxpayers and landowners to provide for them.
Serving others is my strong suit. My leadership skills on the Commissioners Court have helped make Williamson County the nation’s destination for business and the place people want to live.

(1) Public Safety - I always have and always will prioritize public safety by funding it – not defunding it.
(2) Infrastructure - I will continue to enhance safety and mobility in the county by implementing transportation and road improvements.
(3) Lower Taxes – I will continue to adequately fund core services while reducing the property tax rate.

We have partnered with Williamson County cities to attract a diverse group of employers to Williamson County and have created a low regulation environment to help our existing and new businesses remain here. Wilco residents can now live, work, worship and play in the county, fostering a better quality of life.

Williamson County is the county people are moving to because it is still affordable to live here. That didn’t happen by accident. We have kept county government spending in check. I led the charge this year to adopt a residential homestead exemption and to increase the over 65 and disabled persons exemptions. We lowered the property tax rate and the average county tax bill went down as well.

I have led the County in improving our transportation network through the voter approved long range transportation plan and bond programs. As Chair of CAMPO, six county transportation funding organization, I have helped secure hundreds of millions of state and federal dollars for Williamson County and Wilco cities transportation projects. In my next term, I will build on that success.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What are the top three countywide issues you would like to address over your next term, should you be elected?
How will you ensure purposeful growth and development to improve living and business conditions in the county?
How will you improve affordability and reduce the number of people who are unhoused?
How will you address current and future transportation needs in the county?

positions.position: I manage systems that deliver results & have over 25 years of experience managing properties, financials, people, and assets. I look forward to putting these skills to work for Williamson Cty & PCT 4

1.Transparency-proven record
2.Smart Growthmust work collaboratively with all of our smaller government entities to proactively plan for the future and work with all relevant stakeholders as we prepare for more growth; The best way forward is together! 
3.Fiscal Responsibility-I promise to ask the questions, probe for better solutions while increasing the health, safety, and security of the county

The first step I would take is to listen to the people, ask questions- then collaborate with the local government bodies to deliver the identified goals. It is imperative we maintain the quality of life we are so fortunate to experience in PCT 4. I will advocate for what the people want first and foremost-this is what is currently missing. Decisions shouldn’t be made without community buy-in.

I promise to advocate for Property Tax Reform, stand up to bureaucrats who abuse eminent domain, and try to stop the condemning of people’s land and homesteads for private gains. This will keep people in their homes and allow more people to obtain homeownership! High taxes hurt homeowners & I will strongly advocate for reduction in taxes while ensuring the safety of our residents. It can be done!

First and foremost, future planning needs to start now by collaborating with each city’s elected officials and revising current plans to facilitate the explosive growth patterns coming. We must work with local planning and zoning committees to forecast future transportation needs and traffic patterns. It will be a lot of work, but it will make future growing pains less of an issue.

I’ve been the Commissioner for the past 3 years, and Wilco has been my/my family’s home for the past 45 years, I’m a broker/attorney and was appointed to the Brazos River Authority by Governor Abbott.

Neighborhood/family safety is important to me. I oppose radical defunding to the police, like Ausitn as done. As Commissioner I have increased the Sheriff’s budget by $10 million dollars and added 15 positions. I also understand the issue of taxes and have increase the homestead exemptions for seniors, the disabled and families. Lastly, good, high paying jobs for our families and children.

There is no quality of life without a job. That is why I worked to bring companies like Samsung/Apple, that offer good, well-paying jobs for our families and children to Williamson County. I have supported our teachers and students and believe that parents should have a voice in how our school districts run. Our neighborhoods and schools need to be safe places for our families.

As Commissioner I have increased the homestead exemptions for seniors, the disabled and families. Those exemptions have helped decrease property taxes for thousands of citizens and I plan to increase the exemptions as necessary to make Williamson County an affordable place for our seniors and families. Continue to keep the county’s tax rate low by making core services a priority.

Continue to build new roads so that citizens have access to schools, hospitals and jobs. Allowing parents to spend less time on the roads and more time with their families. Local projects like the Southeast Loop will provide an important bridge over Hwy 79 and Union Pacific Railroad and make it safer for citizens, ambulances and school buses to serve the citizens of Williamson County.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
Explain why you would make a fair and impartial Justice of the Peace.
How will you improve the services of the Justice of the Peace?
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
How would you ensure landlords and tenants understand their rights regarding evictions and receive information on available resources?

positions.position: My career in public service began in the DA’s office, bachelor’s degree in Philosophy, certified secondary math teacher and ESL, worked for 2 Congressmen in DC. Paralegal, certified Legislative & OEC

I am compassionate, empathetic and respect all persons, and I am courteous and patient, yet I hold high moral standards and am prepared to make tough decisions and be a fair and impartial jurist on the bench. I believe in a hand up, not a hand out. I am a mother and a grandmother, and I care about our community and future generations, and the well-being of all persons in Williamson County.

The greatest challenge will be to assemble a strong team to get the office back on track to effectively service Precinct 4. In my current position, I helped assemble our successful team, remaining open through a global pandemic, and have ensured the county’s business operations were not disrupted. These are the skills I will continue to use to be an effective JP and to prepare for future growth.

The Justice of the Peace court needs to offer programs to help its constituency work successfully through the court system. Programs like financial education programs, Teen Court and Juvenile Mentoring programs that are being offered by our county’s more dedicated Justices of the Peace. My office will build bridges to connect juveniles with outreach programs and to help families in crisis.

My office will post all landlord and tenant rights on our website, my staff will be available to answer phone calls and questions, and we will ensure landlords who are having difficulties be scheduled on my docket immediately. For the tenants who may need help, my office will compile all county resources available to help with locating housing, paying rent, and meeting every day needs.
31 years in city and county government. Certified in death scene/crime scene investigations, evidence management; municipal code compliance. Masters degree in law. Certified Public Manager.

My years of public service have given me a foundation of diplomacy, discernment, and unbiased delivery of public information and resources to citizens. I am focused on delivering objective and impartial services to the citizens we serve. I put the citizens I serve ahead of any political ideology.

Reopen the office to the public and answer phones. Assess personnel and where they best fit in the organization for efficiency. Assess types of cases on docket and determine which can be processed quickly to get cases adjudicated. Assess digital programs for records and evidence, training for employees on proper use of programs. Consider expansion of hours, alternative dispute resolution.

I will provide a court that is objective and impartial. I will hear and weigh all evidence/testimony from all sides involved in a case, and then make rulings responsibly, fairly, and in accordance with the law. I will work cooperatively, effectively and professionally with the public, other courts, and agency partners.

I will provide information and instructions on the JP4 webpage that will help both landlords and tenants to file and respond to eviction cases. Links to websites for Tenants Rights Handbook, Texas Tenant Advisor, Texas Attorney General, and the Texas State Law Library will be included on the JP4 webpage. Printed instruction materials will be provided upon request to either party of an eviction.
I believe managing an Air Force Orderly Room, combined with my experience as a military court bailiff and years of classroom management have helped prepare me for the office of Justice of the Peace.

Ideally, a great Justice of the Peace should be free from connections or loyalties that would unfairly influence their ability to remain fair and impartial, which is why I have refused any endorsements from law enforcement agencies while other candidates have sought them out. I believe the citizens of Williamson County deserve a Justice of the Peace who promotes equal justice for all.

I believe that the JP office should remain open and continue to operate, which it isn’t doing now, and that the office should focus much more on serving the needs of the people. I have served this community as a public school teacher for more than 25 years, and I will continue to put the needs or our children first, make safety a priority, and get back to serving the people in a timely manner.

John Adams, one of our Founding Fathers, said that we are “government of laws, not of men,” meaning that to maintain order in a civilized society, we must have the law as a foundation. Therefore, justice must be administered fairly and impartially to all. I believe that by preserving this idea, we will maintain the qualities that have made Williamson County such a great place to live.

As a school teacher, I have spent a lifetime educating the people of Williamson County. I believe a good understanding of the eviction process, the rights of tenants, and a decent respect to the idea of being a good neighbor should work together to help people understand the options available to them, so that all stakeholders have the information necessary to make the best decisions.

races.description: Advocates for home district. The House of Representatives has equal legislative functions and powers with the senate; however, only the House may originate revenue and appropriation bills. Shares power with the Senate to levy taxes, borrow money, regulate interstate commerce and declare war. 2-year term.

Advocates for home district. The House of Representatives has equal legislative functions and powers with the senate; however, only the House may originate revenue and appropriation bills. Shares power with the Senate to levy taxes, borrow money, regulate interstate commerce and declare war. 2-year term.

Advocates for home district. The House of Representatives has equal legislative functions and powers with the senate; however, only the House may originate revenue and appropriation bills. Shares power with the Senate to levy taxes, borrow money, regulate interstate commerce and declare war. 2-year term.

issues.question: What in your background qualifies you to serve as the representative for US House Texas D21?
What federal election laws should be changed?
What are your recommendations to improve the immigration system?
What do you see as your role as a representative in Congress with regard to climate change?
What are the top three issues you would like to address if elected and why?

positions.position: I have served as Chairman of the Veteran Affairs Advisory Committee for the City of San Marcos, as well as Chairman for the SMPD Training Advisory Committee. I also served in the Ad Hoc Use of Force Committee to revise SMPD guidelines. I currently serve on the Parks and Recreation Board. I am used to enacting guidelines and reviewing materials to enhance quality of life for people. I’ve worked in finance, tourism, retail, and taxes throughout my life. Giving me a unique perspective on a lot of issues.
We have to ensure the John Lewis Voting Rights Act is signed into law to protect the integrity of our democracy.

We have to explore a comprehensive approach involving the Department of Homeland Security, various state & local governments directly affected, nations of origin to increase opportunities and safety in those countries, as well as the State Department. We have to create a simpler system for a guest worker program to be enacted, increase cross border trade and tourism (revitalize border areas), implement a fair and equitable pathway to citizenship, and document immigrants already here who do not look for citizenship but want to pay taxes and be integrated into our society.

We have to advance our society and be at the forefront of innovation in reducing our carbon footprint. Other countries are way ahead of our country in adopting green initiatives, we could work with those countries to streamline our movement into the future to being a leader around the world in climate change and initiatives. We have the best technology and the best minds to reach that goal.

Infrastructure – Our roads and bridges are falling apart and we are not keeping up with the incredible growth that Texas is facing.
Middle Class – We have to revisit the Build Back Better plan to alleviate the cost of living that is squeezing our middle class families and hindering the working class’ ability for upward mobility.
Immigration – Fix it once and for all, it will help both the other issues above by expanding our tax base and providing the manpower needed to rebuild roads and bridges and lower property taxes by building more homes at a faster pace.

I have dedicated my career to serving my community as a quality healthcare advocate and to my country in the Army Reserve. I have been a leader in my field, working with different disciplines and backgrounds to achieve initiatives that impact thousands of lives. I am a graduate of the Goldman School of Public Policy at UC, Berkeley and have completed analysis of policies that affect the district. Finally, I am a father and want to make things better for our children.

I believe the John Lewis Voting Rights Act needs to be passed to restore federal pre-clearance. The bill would expand oversight into election seats and jurisdiction boundary changes, redistricting, voter I.D. requirements, multilingual voting materials, voter roll maintenance, voting locations, and voting opportunities. We have already observed how these areas can be manipulated to maintain power and systematically decrease the participation of certain voters. We want to have more people to participate in the voting process, not less.

Immigration reform starting with pathway to citizenship for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients followed by a process for Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA). Increase visa quotas and migrant worker programs to reflect the need and ability to process them. Someone should not have to wait 20 years to receive citizenship.

My role with climate change is by accelerating the transition from fossil fuels into renewables. We are not going to shut off oil and gas without thinking about the people this affects. This transition needs to lead by creating higher paying jobs in the renewable energy industry where oil and jobs are. We have to show ERCOT is accountable with the Texas grid, that it can ramp up to our energy needs and not fail ever again. I support energy independence and renewables in Texas to reduce carbon emissions and greenhouse gases.

I support the right to a women’s choice and funding planned parenthood because reproductive health is access to care. I will work to expand affordable housing projects because we need to think about the long-term effects this housing disparity causes to our communities. I support public, private, and non-profit solutions to address affordable housing in both rural and urban cities. Healthcare access is not merely about having health insurance; it also includes improving access to medical facilities through transit options, reducing costs of prescription drugs and out-of-pocket expenses related to health care, as well as the cost of insurance overarchingly.

David is the Founder, President and CEO of Divine Equality (501c3) Nonprofit The former Secretary for Titanium Strong Foundation for Polycythemia Research, Former Southern Careers Institute Board of Advisors Member. San Antonio Community Activist
No response

Immigrants bring diversity to our great country. That why I support the American Dream and Promise Act. There are currently 11+ million undocumented immigrants who are currently living in the United States. We do not need to deport them; we need to make them American citizens. I will fight to Abolish ICE and repeal the 10-year ban that blocks immigrants who have been deported from returning to their families.

2020 is tied with 2016 for the hottest year on record. The earth is basically on fire. We need to take global warming more seriously before it is too late. We are burning forests, Antarctica’s ice is melting, and we are getting record heat days daily. That is why if I get elected to Congress, I will support the Green New Deal. We have to save our planet before it is too late.

Education Reform - We are the best country in the world, but we have kids in High school that are reading on a third-grade level. Texas is the best state in America, but we are ranked 41st nationwide in classroom spending.
Universal Basic Income- I believe that America needs a universal basic income of $1,000/month, $12,000 a year, for every American adult over 18.
Medicare For All- America is one of the world’s largest economies, and yet, too many of our citizens suffer due to healthcare issues. Healthcare costs have skyrocketed over the past few decades.

The people of TX-21 deserve a representative eager to serve, someone who shows up and does their job. A career in education and non-profit leadership gave me the tools to succeed in Washington, teaching me the importance of empathy and compassionate leadership. I’ve survived within the limitations of minimum wage, and know too well how to stretch a dollar. I come from a family of hard-working people who grind tirelessly, hoping one day they’ll be rewarded. I’m running for Congress to meet that hope with action and guarantee every American basic human rights.

Election Day must be a federal holiday to guarantee every American a full day off to vote. We must make voter registration automatic, and provide easily accessible mail-in ballot drop boxes and 24-hour voting locations for those who work untraditional hours. While the idea is to minimize long lines to vote, it should never be made illegal to provide water and snacks to those waiting to vote. Lastly, we need to pass legislation guaranteeing no one is threatened by “independent vote watchers” or other groups of that nature with an intent to intimidate and harass voters.

It’s time to stop treating the southern border like a warzone. Instead of investing in more into an already aggressive security budget, we need to reform the system administratively and invest money into programs that will employ case workers to help migrants keep track of paperwork and reduce the number of overstayed visas, which is one of the main causes for undocumented status for immigrants to the United States. We must also streamline the citizenship application by removing classist financial barriers and creating an easy-to-understand guide to help applicants get all documentation and forms submitted correctly and on time.

It’s my responsibility as your representative to fight for legislation that will address the climate crisis with bold action that achieves net zero carbon emissions by 2050 and makes clean energy accessible and affordable for all Americans. Many residents of TX-21 rely heavily on the natural landscape for tourism-driven income. From the inns and cabins along the Frio River to the countless wineries and wedding venues in Dripping Springs, our district’s beauty fuels our economy and bold climate action is the only way to keep our communities beautiful for visitors drawn in by our Central Texas charm and each other.

We must pass the For the People Act, the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act, and the Build Back Better Act, all of which are vital to the security of Democracy and the success of our citizens, but it’s my hope that they are passed before we win in November. Three issues I would like to address: legalizing and decriminalizing marijuana to create influx of revenue and reduce the market for illegally sourced drugs, expanding education to offer better support for neuro-divergent students, and taking action to halt the effects of climate change.

I am an active non-profit volunteer and community organizer, former Texas legislative aide with a history of policy development, and I am an experienced workforce and budget analyst for the Texas Health and Human Services Commission. I have dedicated hundreds of hours to our community by advancing democracy and volunteering on federal, state, and local campaigns to hosting PPE and vaccine drives for our most vulnerable to protesting human right’s violations across the State—I always show up.

We must address issues within our voting practices and mediums while protecting and encouraging civic engagement. Democracy is under attack, and we need to implement federal uniform voting laws that currently exist in the For the People Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Act. These Acts restore crucial protections against racial voter discrimination, create automatic and same-day voter registration, restore the full protections of the Voting Rights Act, combat voter suppression and gerrymandering. We must also overturn Citizen’s United. Additionally, I champion unique policies such as post-office voter centers and public library cards qualifying as voter identification.

We need a complete overhaul of the inhumane immigration system to mitigate the humanitarian crisis that has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 and climate crisis. I recommend we begin by rescinding Title 42, ending family separation, ending for-profit detention center contracts, upholding domestic and international asylum laws, providing funding to expedite asylum cases, creating an independent oversight commission of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency, and expanding protections for temporary and unauthorized workers. We must develop a roadmap to citizenship that is welcoming and does not inundate future citizens with prohibitive costs, fees, and penalties.

I support the creation of a Civilian Climate Corp to prioritize job security while promoting green energy and clean practices. TX-21 needs EPA guidelines and accountability mechanisms to end flaring. The District suffers from poor air quality due to cement plants and rock quarries; I would expand regulations and commission a study to determine the correlated impacts these practices have on rural health. TX-21 is located above Edward’s Aquifer which is set to be pumped dry by 2070. I would call for non-sustainable pumping methods to be fined and held accountable for the longterm impact they have on the community.

I would prioritize expanding food accessibility, ensuring that people have access to healthy food and grocery stores. No one should have to spend up to 3 hours commuting to their closest grocery store. I would prioritize environmental regulation to protect the beauty of Texas hill country and make sure folks have clean, drinkable water and air that is not contaminated by cement plants, rock quarries, and metal recycling facilities. I would prioritize universal healthcare and increased preventive and routine healthcare clinics in rural areas. Having insurance, Medicaid, or VA benefits does not benefit those who lack access to healthcare facilities.

I’ve been both a homeowner and homeless; I know what it’s like to live paycheck to paycheck; I know the fear of not knowing when your next meal is coming; I know what it’s like to not be able to afford dental care and be afraid of going to the doctor due to not being able to afford it; I know what it’s like to have crushing school loans; I’ve seen firsthand the difficulties the elderly have with affording care and prescription drugs; I’ve been around for a lot of years and can use that experience in D.C.

In order to reduce the distorting influence of money in our politics, we need to undo the disastrous Citizens United v. FEC ruling and give Congress and the States the power to regulate campaign finance. We must return the voices to the millions of Americans who have been silenced by the special Interests of the powerful and wealthy or we will continue to see a very small oligarchy gain ever-increasing political power.

It is time for Congress to come together and develop a comprehensive immigration policy that is both fair and humane. I oppose the demonizing of immigrants and support a path to citizenship for the millions of immigrants who have been contributing members of our society and from whose labor we have greatly benefited. I know that immigrants contribute tremendous value to our country, and that we would not be the world leader that we are today were it not for them.

America can lead the world in sustainable, profitable and innovative environmental solutions but we need to move quicker and get passed those trying to stop innovation and growth. We need to reduce carbon emissions and shift our current economic incentives from dirty fuels to clean renewable energy industries by ending subsidies to oil and fossil fuel companies, including any direct funding or tax giveaways that rig the game in their favor. I will fight for clean energy and be an advocate for green infrastructure improvements. It’s time to move on from our present predicament to a more sustainable future.

Healthcare – If every major industrialized nation can make health care a right and provide universal coverage to all, it is absurd to suggest that we cannot do the same.
Clean Energy – In most states, renewable electricity would reduce the need to import coal and natural gas. Texas alone spends over 1 billion on net coal import. Renewable energy is new jobs, lower bills, and a cleaner planet.
Minimum Wage – Far too many people are forced to choose between working for a paycheck and caring for a new child or sick loved one, or going to school.

races.description: Advocates for home district. The House of Representatives has equal legislative functions and powers with the senate; however, only the House may originate revenue and appropriation bills. Shares power with the Senate to levy taxes, borrow money, regulate interstate commerce and declare war. 2-year term.

issues.question: What are the top three issues you would like to address if elected? Why?
Do you believe federal election laws should be changed? Explain.
What policy changes, if any, do you believe should be made with regard to immigration?
What do you see as the best way to assure that there is no disparity in the availability of health care in the United States?
What laws should Congress pass regarding climate change, if any?

positions.position: The top three now issues that I will champion to add value and build communities are Neighborhood Initiatives (after school care and childcare)/ Revitalization (business hubs), Our Education System Reform / School Safety, and Workforce Expansion. If Not Now, When?

The federal laws that govern campaign financing are filled with loopholes, and according to the Brennan Center for Justice, there were more than 440 restrictive voting bills drafted in 2020-2021. These are some of the reasons why I support changing federal election laws. Everyone who wants to exercise their right to vote should be able to do so freely. It is the responsibility of the federal government to ensure that, that occurs.

As a immigrant who is now a citizen, I understand the importance of having a pathway to citizenship. This is why I will support policy changes for DACA recipients that provide a path to citizenship. Other immigration policy changes that I support are those regarding asylum seekers, undocumented workers and the processing of unaccompanied minors.

The best way to ensure health care equity, is to improve The Affordable Care Act (maintaining no penalty for preexisting conditions), expand Medicaid, and to work towards universal healthcare. We shouldn’t incur massive debt because of health issues.

To reverse the impact of climate change in the U.S and abroad Congress should pass laws that protect our nation’s natural resource which will help to minimize climate change, pass laws that reduce carbon emissions and investment more in renewable energy, and pass H.Res.755 - Expressing support for the United Nations Climate Change Conference and reaffirming the United States commitment to participate globally in combating climate change.

1) Fight the assault on women’s rights and healthcare. Texas subjects its women to second-class status, restricting access to not just abortion, but to contraception and science-based education. Women of color and their infants face higher mortality rates because of this lack of access. 
2) Empower working families, starting with increasing the minimum wage and implementing paid sick and family leave.
3) Invest in infrastructure improvement, including social infrastructure

Federal election laws desperately need to be changed, starting with the John Lewis Voting Rights Act. Our democracy is under attack and decades of progress on civil rights has been undermined. The Supreme Court made a grave error in eliminating the most impactful parts of the Voting Rights Act, especially preclearance. We need national universal vote by mail and automatic voter registration, and the Senate needs to abolish the filibuster so the new VRA can be passed immediately.

In years prior to my service on the San Antonio City Council, I proudly advocated for DREAMers in the public sphere. The Senate must immediately revive the President’s Build Back Better reconciliation language that would shield 7 million undocumented people from deportation for a decade. We must also demand a pathway to citizenship for the millions of law-abiding, tax-paying residents working in so many communities across the country to realize their own American Dream.

For generations, private health insurance companies ran amok in our country. While they were unregulated, costs skyrocketed and families hurt. People died. Texas has the highest uninsured rate in the country. State leaders must do the moral thing and expand Medicaid like 39 other states have. Congress must expand Medicare for all that want it. We must continue on the progress President Biden has made in improving healthcare outcomes for veterans, and Congress must ban state laws like SB 8.

Our federal government’s response to threats facing our planet hasn’t been substantial enough. Climate change disproportionately impacts people of color, and low-income families. Democrats in Congress should support legislation that promotes energy efficiency, reduces carbon emissions, and increases investment and reliance in renewable energy sources. Texas should be a proud leader in creating renewable energy jobs and Congress should act now to get the fossil fuel industry out of our elections.

Win Economic Justice: We must guarantee our communities good jobs, affordable housing, a stable retirement, and a union wage so the families of TX-35 won’t continue to be left behind.
Climate Crisis: We must tackle the climate crisis head on to protect San Antonio families from future storms, and fix our electric grid.
Protect Democracy: Congress must protect voting rights, worker rights, reproductive rights, and our very democracy.

Our democracy is under attack, especially here in Texas. Whether they are rigging the game through gerrymandering, suppressing votes, falsely claiming voter fraud, or allowing corporate money to control our elections, we must put it to an end. Immediate federal action is needed to protect our democracy. We need to pass legislation restoring the full weight of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, and passing the John Lewis Voting Rights Act to protect and expand our democracy.

We must pass comprehensive immigration reform so that we can protect working people and stop family separations. I have fought against right-wing attacks by helping establish immigrant legal defense funds—including in San Antonio— and coordinating the statewide lawsuit against the Governor’s “Show Me Your Papers” law. In Congress, I will work to reverse all anti-immigrant policies and create a path to citizenship for immigrant families.

No one should rely on GoFundMe to cover their medical bills and prescriptions. I will advocate for Medicare for All so every Texan has access to the doctors and medicines they need to keep their families healthy and safe. I support immediately expanding Medicaid for Texans, investing in public health clinics and food access, and investing in the resources needed to end the COVID-19 pandemic.

Texas is on the front lines of the climate crisis, but we are also a leader in renewable energy. We can create good paying union jobs in renewable energy that do not pollute our environment. We need aggressive federal action to tackle climate change, and we must fix the electric grid, by strengthening federal oversight and connecting to the national grid. We should invest in good jobs, clean energy, and electric public transportation.

In Congress, I will continue to fight for progressive values, just as I have in the Texas Legislature. My priorities would be to codify Roe v Wade on the federal level, to fight for good paying jobs, and to address the housing crisis.

I believe that the Governor of Texas has made it clear his intentions regarding voter suppression and I believe that we need Federal safeguards to ensure that voters are protected regardless of who is in power. I would support the John Lewis Voting Rights Act in Congress and would support any federal legislation that strengths these protections.

Anti-immigrant policy and rhetoric are driving families into the shadows, when we should be welcoming people to become full and productive members of our community regardless of their immigration status. I support comprehensive immigration reform with a path to citizenship and a moral immigration system that reflects historical, geographical and economic reality[.]

We find ourselves in an unprecedented moment as we collectively work to slow the community spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The disruption and suffering caused by this pandemic has been made even worse by deep inequalities in our healthcare system. People need healthcare even if they can’t afford it, and, if sick, they need to be able to stay home from work for our public response to be effective. We must finally expand Medicaid.

Our climate is quickly changing and as we saw earlier this year, our winters are colder than ever. We must continue to invest in green infrastructure to work to combat climate change but we also must make smart investments in energy early. Throughout my time in the Texas Leg, I have fought against Republicans again and again when they introduced legislation that put our climate at risk. In Congress, I will continue to be a champion for climate and will fight to bring more green jobs to Texas.

races.description: Advocates for home district. The House of Representatives has equal legislative functions and powers with the senate; however, only the House may originate revenue and appropriation bills. Shares power with the Senate to levy taxes, borrow money, regulate interstate commerce and declare war. 2-year term.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
How would you ensure election laws provide all eligible voters with equal access to safe and fair elections?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health impacts for those who don’t have access to the health services they need?
What do you see as a U.S. Representative’s role with regard to climate change?
What other issue is your highest legislative priority and what legislation would you introduce or support to address it?

positions.position: Computer Engineer. 18+ yr career in tech. Championed successful products that millions use. 15+ yr in Austin and former president of 4000 member non-profit that provides free training and education.

Ensure that voters have the ability to take off time so they can vote. Expand early voting and vote-by-mail. Allocate polling locations and voting machines based on population density so that wait times are not prohibitive to voting.

Reproductive healthcare decisions should be made between a doctor and the individual seeking care. Lower the cost of healthcare and prescription drugs with Medicare for All. Scale the healthcare infrastructure and improve quality of care with more physicians and nurses. Emphasize primary and preventative care to catch issues early instead of at the ER. Address Latino and Black maternal deaths.

Enact legislation to diversify our energy sources with renewables, incentivize carbon emissions reduction, and phase out subsidies for oil and gas and other carbon producing industries. Promote electrification and expand public transportation infrastructure. Invest in research to mitigate climate change and institute sustainable farming and fishing practices.

Lower the cost of education and eliminate student loans. Champion debt-free education including college, trade school, certifications, and training programs. Enact legislation that promotes in-demand fields: teaching, social work, healthcare, engineering, trades, manufacturing, and technology. Incentivize serving in rural and under-served communities.

Every American with a vision for improving the lives of their family and neighbors is qualified for public office. I plan to legislate with a philosophy of “Do No Harm” to protect all our communities.

We must end partisan gerrymandering to give voters the power to choose their own representation, we must pass the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Act and create a renewed preclearance process to protect voters in jurisdictions with a long history of discrimination, and we must encourage more participation in our electoral process by lowering the barrier of entry for everyday citizens to run for office[.]

We must fight for Reproductive Justice and focus on the entire journey an individual will take when planning for themselves and their family. We must demand uninhibited access to contraceptive care, implement Medicare for All to guarantee healthcare access, protect abortion access, demand 12 weeks of paid family leave, establish permanent child-care credits, and establish universal Pre-K.

We must play a leading role in fighting climate change by 1) incentivizing more investment in green energy technology and the recapture of greenhouse gases, 2) creating regional climate disaster mitigation plans, 3) we must transition our economy away from fossil fuels, 4) and we must also protect workers. That means funding job training and placement programs to ensure no worker is left behind.

My top 2 additional issues are 1) securing equity in our institutions for women, LGBTQ+, Black, Hispanic, and other persons of color, and 2) criminal justice reform through legalizing marijuana, expunging records & releasing non-violent drug offenders, funding more drug rehabilitation programs, paying inmates a fair wage, and restoring voting rights to felons who have completed their sentences.
My background in climate policy and power systems engineering would allow me to deliver practical, effective solutions to combat climate change and safely transition the USA to net-zero emissions.

I think the most important thing is to automatically register people to vote when they turn 18, enroll in a university, or update their license at a DMV when they move. I also support same-day registration at the polls. It is also important to expand what counts as Voter ID, allowing for people to use student IDs, utility bills, leases, and other government or legal documents as identification.

After Texas’ new restrictive abortion law, it’s become clear that Congress must guarantee a woman’s right to an abortion through federal law. In terms of addressing the impacts of lack of health services, we need to both get Medicare to all who want it and have the US government negotiate with the healthcare industry to set fixed, national prices for all prescription drugs and medical procedures.

A Rep’s role should be to allocate financial resources to goals and projects that people and businesses cannot achieve by themselves. Some projects include  modernizing the electricity grid to allow for more renewable electricity, investing more in carbon capture technology to reverse the effects of climate change, or connecting the Texas grid to the US grid to prevent climate-caused blackouts.

The American Dream of having a home and a small family with a decent job and minimal debt is all but dead. An omnibus bill is needed to revive it. This bill would include laws like allowing cities to set minimum wages, banning corporations from buying single-family homes, and providing a one-time $5k individual payment for relief from any debt. For more info, please see my 5x5 plan on my website.

House Ways & Means Health Subcom Chair, Prior Texas State Senator, Texas Supreme Court Justice, Recognitions: “Best of Austin” Austin Chronicle readers 12 times, AARP twice, Sierra Club, NAACP, HABLA.

We face the greatest threat to democracy in my lifetime. Texas is now ground zero for voter suppression. I support the “John Lewis Voting Rights” Act, uniform standards easing voter registration, vote by mail, ending unfair restrictions. The GOP is now less a political party and more a personality cult, willing to use violence or any other means to install authoritarian governance.

Reproductive freedom is fundamental. Endorsed by Planned Parenthood Action. 100% pro-choice lifetime voting record. Rallied against Texas vigilante law, sponsored both Women’s Health Protection Act removing unjust restrictions and Access to Birth Control Act, opposed Hyde amendment & Global Gag rule. Leader on getting more Texans family physician access by closing GOP created health coverage gap.

Sounding crisis alarm, seeking immediate action toward a carbon-neutral future with less fossil fuels/fossilized thinking. Already authored renewable tax incentives, Green Transportation planning, EV charger bills. Joined Carbon Dividend bill, aspirational Green New Deal. To strengthen our national security, boost our economy, stop existential threat, US must be international leader, not laggard.

Seeking better affordable healthcare for more, including adoption of my coverage gap, telehealth, anti pharma price-gouging, dental/hearing/vision benefit, and nursing home safety bills. Remove educational financial barriers, expand Pell Grants, pass my Tax-Free Pell Grants bill, focus on Austin affordability/mobility challenges. Prevent Abbott federal funds diversion from Austin & public schools.

issues.question: What training, experience and characteristics qualify you for this position?
How would you ensure election laws do not create barriers to Texans’ freedom to vote while maintaining safe and secure elections?
What further changes, if any, are needed to ensure that Texas has sufficient power in times of extreme weather conditions?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health consequences for those who seek and cannot obtain abortions in Texas?
What is the role of the state government in enforcing federal immigration laws?

issues.issueName: Autonomy of State and Local Government
issues.question: Under what circumstances should the federal government limit the authority of elected state officials? Under what circumstances should the state government limit the authority of elected local officials?

positions.position: Learned about public service from missionary parents who served people who lived in garbage dumps in MX City Former public school teacher & public radio reporter who learned about the intricacies of TX from the stories of Texans Graduated UT’s LBJWCS

In a Joy Diaz administration, we will ensure that everyone who is entitled to vote, has access to safe and secure elections. Recent restrictions in Texas affect families like mine. My husband is a naturalized US citizen - the perfect target for some of the state’s recent voter purges that only serve to intimidate and even suppress the vote. Those laws have to go.

We need to ensure fines to companies that don’t winterize are not symbolic — meaning, fines are not cheaper than winterization. At the moment, they’re a cheap loop-hole. Texas’ focus ought to be - first - to protect the lives of Texans. The interest of for-profit companies should be second. To ensure oversight, the PUC board can’t be made up solely of political appointees.

As a woman who has gone through all her reproductive cycles & as the only woman on the Dem ticket running for governor - my goal is for every woman in TX to have access to an array of options - from free and easy access to contraceptions to - if necessary - abortions. She and her doctor are the only ones who can decide over her reproductive life. The disrespect stops now.

The Constitution establishes the federal government controls the border - therefore immigration has been and always will be a federal responsibility. But, Texas has a role to play. We need to partner with both the US and MX governments. At the moment, TX has not been a helpful partner. Instead, state policies have contributed to the chaos for political gain.

Only extreme circumstances merit the intervention of the federal government in state matters. The same is true for the state overpowering local governments. By “extreme”, I mean emergencies such as natural disasters or circumstances in which public health or human rights are threatened. During COVID, TX has overpowagainst the wisdom of health experts.

I was the President of the Southeast Texas Toyota Dealers association when I secured the naming rights of the Toyota Center. It is we’re the Houston Rockets play. My team had great confidence that I could secure the more than 100 million $ contract.
I was arrested in Washington DC fighting for voter suppression bills that are now Law. As Governor I will beto those bills and call special sessions to revoke those bills.

It is common sense Governing as we just do the required maintenance. The current Governor is so focused on not working with a Democratic President. We should do repairs beyond what the federal Government requires. The same oil and gas companies made millions on Texans that donated 1 million in to his campaign.

Again I have skin in the game as I arrested protesting in the streets of DC, against the heart beat bill. As a person that studied the HIPPA LAWS as I achieved my Masters in Psychology I found out that your medical issues are private and no one else’s concerns. As Governor I will work to over turn that law.

It is the federal Governments job to secure the boarder. We can work alongside them, but we should not spend 250 million dollars on a fence that does not work. We need to spend any extra money or donated money on teachers pay raise, repairing Dilapidated schools and money for pre-K for all children. We should make all remaining noncitizens - citizens sooner than later.

If a State or local official is not acting in kind towards the citizens, I believe we would never had integrated schools if it were not for the federal Government forcing Governor Wallace to allow Blacks in all white schools. In Texas we are run by a Republican Party does not recognize all people equal. The federal Government should pass the John Lewis voters act to help.

Beto O’Rourke is a fourth-generation Texan, born and raised in El Paso where he has served as a small business owner, a city council member and a member of Congress. He founded Powered by People, a Texas-based voting rights and service organization.

We can’t have fair, safe, and secure elections if our laws are designed to make it harder for communities of color to vote. We must repeal SB1 and then pass online and same-day voter registration, establish nonpartisan redistricting commissions, require the convenient and fair allocation of voting sites, and expand eligible forms of voter ID.

To ensure power for all Texans we must weatherize all elements of the grid – including gas supply, connect to the national grid, provide backup generation at critical facilities like nursing homes, invest in targeted energy efficiency programs, starting with low-income Texans most in need of ratepayer assistance, and provide immediate relief and protection for ratepayers.

We should trust Texas women to make their own reproductive health care decisions. If elected governor, Beto will immediately work to repeal SB8 and the dangerous system that places a bounties on the heads of anyone who supports a woman in deciding her own future.

We need predictability, order, and the rule of law at our border. We need a governor willing to collaborate with, not work against, the federal government to enforce our immigration laws and update those laws when they don’t meet the challenges of today.

The divisions of authority between state and federal officials and state and local officials, are described in the federal and Texas constitutions (and subsequent statutes), respectively. An elected official’s authority should be limited when the official acts in excess of their constitutional and statutory authority or otherwise violates the constitution or law.

Licensed Engineer & Attorney & Business Owner; Policy Advisor to Commissioner Anderson, Public Utility Commission of Texas April 2013 - April 2018; Retired nuclear submarine Navy Reserve Captain w/ 4 Commands; Power generation and ERCOT expertise.

Trust but verify! Make registration simple, secure and verifiable. Increase the time period for early voting. Remove restrictions on Church organized voter turnout efforts and restrictions on Church organized voter transportation. Enable Church based efforts to register their parishioners and deliver them to the polls.

Reliability can be achieved by a balance of thermal & renewable generation coupled with grid and generation testing. Since 2015 ERCOT has lost 3,000 MW of thermal generation while experiencing growth of over 17,000 MW of wind & solar. An 83%-17% thermal to renewable ratio provides reliability and allows Texas to satisfy the EPA’s Clean Power Plan goals. Invest in Texas!

U.S. Supreme Court Decisions establish the law of the land, whether or not one agrees with the decisions. Attempts by states to subvert or undermine those decisions are a direct attack on the U.S. Constitution. Women must have the right to control their own bodies. Texas women who seek abortions consistent with Supreme Court law should not be denied access by state laws.

None, Both party’s administrations have been inept at stopping illegal immigration; therefore do not follow the federal government’s approach. Immigration is caused by economics. Texas must build an economic wall, not a physical wall. If we make them pay to be in Texas, we will reduce illegal immigration. Don’t wait on the Feds, Texas can take its own economic action.

Federal limiting of State Officials: Only if the health, safety, or welfare of the public is in danger by state official’s actions. State limiting of Local Officials: Only if the health, safety, or welfare of the public is in danger by local official’s actions. Authority for decisions should be held at the lowest level of government to keep citizens engaged and empowered.

issues.question: What training, experience and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What further changes, if any, are needed to ensure that Texas has sufficient power in times of extreme weather conditions?

issues.issueName: Autonomy of State and Local Government
issues.question: Under what circumstances should the federal government limit the authority of elected state officials? Under what circumstances should the state government limit the authority of elected local officials?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health consequences for those who seek and cannot obtain abortions in Texas?
What are some solutions to enhance public safety in Texas? How do we balance these solutions with protecting civil rights?

positions.position: I was elected to the Texas Legislature in 2018 and became the first Democrat to ever represent District 65 in Denton County. I said I would fight for healthcare, education, & the environment and did. This led to an improved margin win in 2020.

The 87th legislature did not do enough. Texas needs to reverse the course of deregulation and consider the option of connecting back to the national grid. El Paso & Texarkana did not lose power like the rest of the state, both are connected to the national grid.

Texas has been controlled by the GOP for over 25 years. State officials are running amuck due to checks & balances that no longer exist. The federal government needs to address the Voting Rights Bills. We saw our freedom to vote diluted as well as extreme gerrymandering in 2021. The state government should not interfere with local health regulations.

The attacks on women’s healthcare should not continue. I voted against HB8. There should not be $10,000 bounties on women & health professionals. A womans’s choice on abortion is between her and her doctor.

I had a city come to me with the issue of a police officer that had been fired with cause now working at a neighboring city. Municipalities should be able to know this information upon hiring or the problems can’t be addressed and will continue. Texas needs to look into solutions to address these issues and solve them.

I have served Texas as an educator, advocate, and Texas Democratic Party Vice-chair as a champion of people and working families. Equity in education, economics, opportunity, and justice is the best way to move Texas forward for all people.

We must fully weatherize our grid to prepare for extreme weather conditions. We need to fully accept the recommendations of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and prepare all of Texas for climate change. We must build better oversight, accountability, and transparency to insure Texans from another failure.

It is the responsibility of each government entity to work together for the benefit of the people that they serve. We live and serve in a representative democracy and to limit the authority of a government to do what is best for the people is taking away their representation.

I am in full support of a woman’s right to make choices for her reproductive health. We must provide education and access to every woman in Texas to make the best choice for her and her family. We also must support women by advocating for safe abortions across this state and making way for that to happen even under this archaic law.

Every community should feel safe in their own home and neighborhood and experience their civil rights and liberties. We must start with continuous training for our officers with emphasis on inclusion and diversity, including (1) recruiting, hiring, and promoting women in leadership and (2) increasing community-centered policing, particularly in communities of color.

Mike spent his career as a CPA and an auditor at PriceWaterhouseCoopers before becoming a CFO of a Texas energy company, helping create good-paying jobs. His experience as an accountant gives him a deep understanding of how our state’s budget works.

For years, our state leaders were warned about the grid’s vulnerability and did nothing. As a result, Texans froze, Texans died, and corporations got rich. We must winterize our gas supply, invest in smart grid technology, and increase power storage. We must also ensure that Texas families do not pay more when companies pay less for an unreliable grid.

If the behavior of any official is inconsistent with our constitutional rights, then it is the responsibility of the federal government, particularly the courts, to step in. That said, local control is key to accountability, and it’s at the heart of a healthy democracy. So, as Lt. Governor, I will work closely with duly elected local partners—not against them.

Mike will defend our constitutional rights so that women will be masters of their own health and their own destinies. The Principles laid down by Roe v Wade and have guided us for nearly the last fifty years are reasonable and are supported by the vast majority of Americans.

Mike will work to reverse laws that allow criminals to access firearms and put our communities and law enforcement officers at risk. Further, we all want law enforcement that we know, trust, and are accountable to our local communities. We must also invest more in mental health training and restorative justice to create safer, more prosperous communities across Texas.

issues.question: What training, experience and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What is the Attorney General’s role in protecting Texans’ freedom to vote while maintaining safe and secure elections?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health consequences for those who seek and cannot obtain abortions in Texas?
What is the role of the state government in enforcing federal immigration laws?
As Attorney General, what would be your highest priorities for the next four years, and how do you intend to accomplish them?

positions.position: I have experience in immigration, family, criminal, and constitutional law. My work has resulted in the “Garza Notice,” a requirement that teens in immigration detention have a right to access abortion, reinforcing a constitutional right nationwide.

As AG, I will dismantle the wasteful “election integrity unit” — which is really about enforcing the GOP’s voter suppression measures, instead of protecting voting rights — and replace it with a voter protection unit under a fully funded civil rights department. I will ensure voting rights are protected, not undermined, especially for voters of color.

Abortion care is health care, and health care is a human right. Reproductive choice is a moral imperative and an issue of racial, economic, and gender justice. I’m committed to restoring abortion access in TX and defending the rights of women and pregnant people anywhere they’re threatened. I’ve defended reproductive rights before and will do so as TX AG.

Immigration enforcement falls under federal jurisdiction. As an immigration attorney & border native, I understand the complexities of our immigration system. I have litigated against bad policies, like Remain in Mexico, that have created a humanitarian crisis at the border. Texas’ enforcement efforts at the border are unconstitutional, wasteful and only worsen the issue.

As AG, I will fight for our Texas families. This means protecting constitutional rights, including voting & abortion rights; consumer protection, so our energy grid doesn’t fail; and prioritizing public health, so municipalities & schools can protect people in the middle of a pandemic and our rural communities have the infrastructure they need, like clean drinking water.

Licensed TX attorney; 30 years’ experience in trial/appellate litigation in TX state and federal courts. TX mediator; 8 years local govt. experience: councilmember, mayor pro tem and mayor of Galveston,TX. Mentored by my grandfather Leon Jaworski.

I will form a voter access unit from the ashes of the AG’s fake voter fraud division because TX voters should turn to the AG’s office when their voting rights are suppressed.
