Only the house can impeach a statewide officer.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
How would you ensure election laws provide all eligible voters with equal access to safe and fair elections?
What is your position on reproductive rights and how would you address the economic and health impacts for those who don’t have access to the health services they need?
What are your top priorities for public education?
What is your highest legislative priority for funding, and would you be willing to use Texas’s “rainy day fund” to finance it?

positions.position: I come from a place of serving my community - from volunteering throughout DVISD to working to get the 2019 school bond passed. I would lead with wholeheartedness, compassion and a serving mindset.

Democracy is like a muscle and we must exercise it frequently. We have to make it as easy as possible for people to participate in the government, be it voting or sharing their voice with elected officials. Vote by mail should be an option for any Texan. We should have more polling locations in places where residents go (like schools, grocery stores). We need longer voting hours as well.

Healthcare is a human right. It’s a disgrace that our nation does not have a universal healthcare system. It’s also horrible we do not teach our children science based, sex education that respects their mind and bodies. If we started here, we would have an easier time agreeing that Texans must have bodily autonomy. Only they should decide if an abortion is right for them, not the government.

My top education priority is teacher and staff retention. Public education across the nation is at a breaking point. Our educators are over worked, under paid and stressed from the lingering pandemic. They deserve the public’s thankfulness and support, not additional pressure from book bans and parents crying ‘parental choice’. Students will be best served when their teachers feel valued.

Education needs more money. I have seen in my own local school how the staff pulls together whatever they can (usually through community donations) to provide families with food, clothes and healthcare. They are resourceful but they shouldn’t have to be educators and solicit for children’s basic needs to be met. Texas needs to step up. If we can spend $1Billion on a wall, we can invest in schools.
I’ve managed hotels for 5 years, run international non-profits, and am highly educated on policy, history, and legislative procedure here in Texas. I also have extensive organizing experience.

I would:
-Expand polling hours and locations
-Provide more training and payment to all poll workers
-Expand access to mail in voting -Allow online voter registration and enact automatic voter registration for Texans who turn 18 -Outlaw partisan gerrymandering and implement an independent commission to draw new congressional maps in the state of Texas

It is a pregnant person’s decision what happens to their body, no one else’s, I believe access to abortion should be without restriction. To expand access I would:
-Retract the heartbeat acts and fund access to abortions for all pregnancies
-Expand comprehensive health coverage for those able to become pregnant to cover pre & post-natal care
-Expand Medicaid, Medicare, and CHIP networks

Priority 1. Increase teachers’ pay to at least $70k/year and tie it to cost of living to automatically increase with inflation
2. Enable all Texans, regardless of documentation status, to be able to attend Texas primary and secondary schools and get in-state tuition for college
3. Provide clean and safe water in Texas schools by funding the replacement of lead and copper pipes

My #1 issue is bringing down housing costs. To the extent that this relies on public funding, it would be to build more housing that is denser & more affordable in our cities. We must approach homelessness with a Housing First strategy that relies on getting folks in homes, not shelters. As for the rainy day fund, I would be happy to use it. Homelessness is a crisis in TX, it’s already raining.
Lawyer with 25+ years Capitol experience. Former President, National Women’s Political Caucus. Longtime community volunteer, including Planned Parenthood, YMCA Austin, and Austin Arts Commission.

We must reverse voter suppression laws, ban partisan intimidation at polling locations, and end voter purges. I support online, same day, and automatic voter registration as well as universal vote by mail. I will combat state interference of counties seeking to add polling places, extend voting hours, and increase access. I’ll also advocate for federal passage of the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

As a former Planned Parenthood board member and longtime abortion rights advocate, I’ll fight to repeal SB 8 and its invitation to harass patients and providers. I’ll work to reverse the ban on Planned Parenthood from Title X funding and demand real accountability on so-called “crisis pregnancy centers.” I support Medicaid expansion, CHIP access, and addressing the shortage of doctors and nurses.

Teacher burnout and learning loss were greatly exacerbated by COVID-19. Addressing these issues requires a holistic approach, including: raising teacher pay, eliminating pressure to teach to the test, reducing inequities in broadband access and STEM, strengthening our commitment to social emotional learning, and addressing childhood food insecurity. The state must increase public school funding.

Years of one-party rule have left a costly legacy of neglect. Smart moves, like Medicaid expansion, would allow us to tap into federal dollars to strengthen healthcare infrastructure. Ensuring an educated workforce and addressing the reliability of the electric grid requires private and public investment. The state’s replenishing “rainy day fund,” with $10+ Billion in it, should be used as needed.

I’m a former special education teacher, Vice President of the Del Valle
Community Coalition, and Vice-Chair of the City of Austin Early Childhood Council. My background is heavily in public service.

Instead of prioritizing participation in our democracy, the Texas legislature most recently spent its time making it harder for Texans to efficiently vote. If elected, I would work to expand the opportunities for Texans to exercise their right to vote, including mediums in which Texans can register to vote, such as online registration and overturning SB 1, which made voting much harder in Texas.

Yes, I believe reproductive care is healthcare, and I am a candidate for increasing access to healthcare for any Texan who needs it. Not all Texans who can get pregnant are women, and not all women menstruate. HD 51 is a district that faces a major lack of health clinics. I would push for investments to ensure public health agencies are equipped to efficiently and effectively in the district.

I’m a former public special education teacher so I know firsthand the struggles teachers face in the classroom. My priorities include ensuring that districts with larger concentrations of poverty and need have greater access to funding, advocating for a cost of living adjustment for current and retired educators, and prioritizing state, local, and federal funding for ISD’s.

HD 51 is in serious need of critical infrastructure updates. We are a food desert, and lack transit and healthcare clinics to take care of our constituents. My highest priority would working towards investments in Texas’s infrastructure to help HD 51 and other areas of the state that need the investments. Winter Storm Uri was detrimental to Texas and we can’t afford to be caught off guard again.

I grew up in HD 51 & have been active in the community my entire life. My experiences have given me familiarity with the concerns of my community, the people and institutions to address their concerns

I will oppose any laws that make it harder to vote. Instead, we need to pursue reforms that will increase voter access and participation, including online voter registration, automatic voter registration, and universal vote-by-mail. These policies have been successful in both red and blue states across our country in improving the accessibility, security, and efficiency of elections.

I support the repeal of abortion restrictions including the six-week abortion ban and a full restoration of the rights guaranteed to women under Roe. Additionally, we must take action to reduce our high uninsured rate by expanding Medicaid under the ACA to over 700,000 Texans at little cost to the state.

We must continue to reform our school finance system and ensure that state funding is at least 50%, which will reduce the burden on property taxpayers. We must also ensure our investments are prudent, sustainable, and will improve the quality of education. This means increasing teacher pay and focusing on evidence-based interventions such as early phonics education.

My top priority will be fully funding the state’s share of public education, so that teachers are well-paid, students receive a quality education, and property tax increases are limited. However, I would not use the Rainy Day Fund, which is for one-time expenses such as disaster response. Instead, we need stable sources of state revenue to support long-term investments in education.

races.description: 2-year term. The House is one of two chambers that make up the Texas legislature. The representative is one of 150 representatives. They make and vote on laws, decide where the money goes within the state government, serve on committees such as agriculture and livestock, business and industry, elections, higher education, energy resources, etc. Bills for raising money must originate in the house. Only the house can impeach a statewide officer.

2-year term. The House is one of two chambers that make up the Texas legislature. The representative is one of 150 representatives. They make and vote on laws, decide where the money goes within the state government, serve on committees such as agriculture and livestock, business and industry, elections, higher education, energy resources, etc. Bills for raising money must originate in the house. Only the house can impeach a statewide officer.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: For twenty-three years, I’ve fought for justice for all. I will bring my two decades of broad experience as a litigator, collaborator, and Family Law expert to run a court that serves our community.

A judge needs to be unbiased and legally competent. I’ve demonstrated these qualities while practicing law for more than twenty-three years and earning a Board Certification in Family Law, a qualification held by only 823 attorneys in the state. Likewise, I’ve developed policies for the children in Texas while managing state and federal legislation for the Office of the Attorney General.

Sixty percent of the cases in District Courts are family law matters and the other thirty percent are personal injury, real estate, and other civil matters. Therefore, our courts must work for our families. I want to implement a night court to help our working community. I’ve also begun conversations with community leaders and organizations to expand job and mental health opportunities.

Immediately after law school, I formed a free legal clinic to help marginalized communities. My unbiased and welcoming approach will guarantee that everyone who appears before me is heard and that the law is applied. As Judge, I will partner with the Austin Bar Association to encourage more attorneys to volunteer to provide legal aid. I will also develop programs that improve court access.

While campaigning, I’ve asked and listened to attorneys and “everyday people” about suggested improvements for our District Courts. My plans are to immediately review court statistics to determine if backlogs are occurring. Also, I will review current best practices while implementing new ideas from stakeholders and experts. Finally, I will consistently “render speedy and quick decisions”.

I am a multilingual (Spanish and Portuguese) award-winning lawyer, credentialed mediator, and civil trial lawyer. Additionally I am a U.S. Army Infantry Medic Veteran with 8 years of honorable service

The combination of excellence and recognition in a lawyer’s career combined with empathy, cultural awareness, and social intelligence. In my opinion, being a great lawyer alone does not make a good judge. We need the whole package. As a mom, immigrant, veteran, small business owner, and award-winning lawyer, I have a unique combination of skills that will add positively to our judiciary.

If I am elected I will be the first immigrant and female veteran to ever serve in a District Court in Travis County. Our population is approximately 32% percent Latino at this time and growing. My background as an award-winning lawyer, immigrant, and veteran makes it so that I have the tools to recognize and build programs to enhance and build access to the courts by those who are often neglected.

Low-income individuals and families - often Latinos, Black and Brown families, face more barriers to obtaining justice. I am committed to helping those who have to represent themselves due to financial restraints by expanding the services provided by the law library as much as possible, including advocating for the addition of more bilingual speaking lawyers to assist those with language barriers.

I think we need to combine the continued use of zoom for appropriate cases with in-person hearings as soon as it is healthy for people to gather in courtrooms. Combining and adapting the use of technology that has proven to be effective will allow Judges to hear more cases in a day efficiently. As a small business owner I am accustomed to efficiently running a law practice and this will transfer.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: Current Judge of this court, 30 year trial lawyer, 20 years Board Certified in Family Law. Recipient of the 2011 Litigation Attorney Award from the Travis County Women Lawyers’ Association.

I’ve spent thousands of hours working pro bono on cause-oriented litigation, including serving as Chief Counsel on the case of Goodfriend v. DeBeauvoir, which resulted in the court ruling that allowed the marriage of the first same-sex couple in the history of Texas. This experience has deepened my commitment to ensure that our courts are there to serve all.

Our civil courts protect our liberties, democracy, and public safety. An injunction I issued permitting mask mandates in local schools is just one example. Every litigant wants a judge who knows the law and is fundamentally fair. My focus has been to ensure the highest standards in our courts, while integrating new technologies that promote access, and always guarding the right to trial by jury.

As the Immediate Past Chair of Volunteer Legal Services, I understand the imbalances in the system and that demand for representation often exceeds the availability of pro bono attorneys. Nevertheless, I organized attorneys to help people facing evictions during COVID-19. Our justice system can only work when every person has equal access to a level playing field in their search for justice.

We established new procedures for zoom hearings in order to prevent a large backlog of cases in contested civil cases. I am proud to be working with stakeholders and community leaders to develop new and innovative procedures for our courts, especially as it relates to jury selection. This will ensure justice for all, while protecting the health and safety of our community

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: 28-year trial attorney & lifelong Democrat. If elected, I’ll be the first openly gay civil district judge. Dedicated public servant & volunteer. As a Judge, I’ll be committed to equal justice for all.

A good judge should bring legal experience and empathy. I work with people who are indigent on their eviction and divorce cases. Many of them need access to mental health, trauma, and addiction resources. As a judge, I will strive to level the playing field to provide justice to every person, including our most vulnerable.

Our civil courts play a crucial role in protecting democracy, defending the rights of workers, expanding voting rights, & protecting the environment. The use of virtual hearings during COVID has expanded access to justice allowing people to participate in court regardless of work, health, or family obligations. I will continue to use these technologies to ensure accessibility & justice for all.

Equal access to justice in the courtroom starts outside the courtroom. I will continue to be a strong advocate for resources like Volunteer Legal Services and the Travis County Law Library that provide free legal services to the indigent and increase access to justice. Inside the courtroom, I will advocate for ADA accessibility and translators. Our courts must serve the public and be open to all.

To clear the backlog caused by COVID-19, I will continue the virtual submission docket. This allows uncontested cases to be resolved quickly and inexpensively while time and resources are devoted to contested matters. Once in-person trials resume, I will allow witnesses and experts to appear virtually to prevent further delays and to ensure justice.
Over twenty-five years of civil trial law experience. Board Certified, Administrative Law; B.A., Government, UT Austin; M.A., Public Administration, UH; J.D, South Texas College of Law Houston.

Fairly administered justice requires the commitment to follow the Texas Code of Judicial Conduct. I will perform my judicial duties without bias or prejudice based on race, sex, religion, national origin, disability, age, sexual orientation, or socioeconomic status. I have shown and continue to show fairness towards others in my daily living experiences, law practice, and legal profession.

District Court is where people can receive “fair, effective, and efficient resolution of civil and family disputes.” Litigants want their day in court and they want to be heard. I will work with the court administrator to give them the opportunity to be heard. I will make sure I am prepared and available to give each litigant the care and attention they deserve in their case.

For equal access to the courts, I will work with court administrators to improve access to and use of indigent legal service fees. Interpreters are available via the Travis County LEP Plan. For equal justice, I will perform my judicial duties without bias or prejudice based on race, sex, religion, national origin, disability, age, sexual orientation, or socioeconomic status.

I will coordinate with court administrators to identify, reduce, and eliminate any backlogged cases on my docket. I will offer to hear backlogged cases from other dockets. If possible, I will utilize courtroom technology to conduct hearings remotely. I will review the issues in the case before taking the bench. I will issue necessary orders or rulings fairly, diligently, and competently.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps, if any, would you take to support alternatives to imprisonment to minimize the number of incarcerated people?

positions.position: I currently am the Judge of the 331st District Court, seeking re-election. I have handled every aspect of this job for the last three years and would like to continue as your judge for a second term.

Through my three years on the bench, I have proven my commitment to restorative justice while maintaining the safety of our community. I have worked diligently to make my court fair and efficient, so parties can obtain just closure in their cases and be able to move on with their lives.

In my first year in office, I took the lowest performing felony court in Travis County and made it the highest performing felony court. I helped draft a General Order allowing for automatic personal bonds for qualified defendants charged with certain non-violent state jail and third degree felony offense. If re-elected, I would like to improve pretrial bonding procedures and take over drug court[.]

As part of my commitment to restorative justice, I have always allowed all parties an opportunity to be heard and have input in their proceedings, and everyone who comes before my Court is treated with respect and dignity.

I have the highest number of probationers of any felony court in Travis County, providing opportunities to those who can be rehabilitated and want to be rehabilitated with the services and programs they need to become contributing members of our community. For every defendant who is rehabilitated, there is one less criminal in our community. This is how we improve the safety of our community.

Asst. DA specializing in child abuse & animal cruelty. DA’s Office Training Manager for trial skills & techniques, implicit bias, & racial equity. Founder of DA’s Office racial equity discussion group[.]

Humanity. Judges are responsible for impartial application of the law, but should always recognize a person’s dignity in the process. Individuals that enter the system should never be reduced to statistics. A judge should always remember that the issues they preside over directly impact human beings who deserve individual respect and compassion.

I’m running because the 331st District Court needs substantive, progressive change. The court could improve in three areas: consistent and competent application of the law, a deeper emphasis and focus on compassion and empathy for defendants and victims, and increasing the diversity of our judiciary. If elected, I would be the first ever Asian American District Judge in Travis County history.

I would waive costs and fees while promoting easy access to diversion programs. I have a record of not opposing lowering bail amounts & personal bonds for low-risk defendants. Language and ADA accommodations would be made and expanded. Hearings would continue to be a hybrid of in-person and online for better access to courts. Mostly, I’ll remain fair and impartial for defendants and victims alike.

We need robust diversion programs that keep low-level, non-violent, & youthful offenders out of jail. We must explore & implement restorative justice programs. We must create probation conditions that address underlying issues like homelessness, food insecurity, and lack of access to healthcare & education. Similarly, bail must not be excessive or otherwise used as a punitive tool.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps, if any, would you take to support alternatives to imprisonment to minimize the number of incarcerated people?

positions.position: Presiding judge, County Court 6, and attorney working in criminal justice in Travis County for 24 years. Mom of 3 boys, focused on creating innovative solutions to reform the criminal justice system.

Empathy and compassion are critical to ensuring justice for all. As a Judge, I have worked to disrupt the school to prison pipeline and to level the playing field, so that every person before me has the chance to succeed. I created an award winning program allowing teens and young defendants, who are prosecuted as adults in our State, the opportunity to avoid jail and get the support they need.

My experience as a judge has given me a front row view to the problems caused by the gaps in our criminal justice system and an understanding that when an individual’s fundamental needs are met, he or she is more likely to succeed in life. I created Project Engage to help young people, as Texas is 1 of only 3 states across the nation that prosecutes Defendants as young 17, as adults.

A broad spectrum of people come before our criminal courts. Many are indigent, suffer from trauma, mental health issues, and addiction. Teen defendants often do not have a parent appear with them in court. As judge, I must ensure that every defendant receives effective representation and will continue to testify at the Capitol in favor of raising the age in which teens are prosecuted as adults.

In addition to Project Engage, I co-preside over the Travis County Veteran’s Court, which connects our veterans with mental health and social services. Both of these diversion programs help people in our community receive access to resources and support. I will continue to fight to expand diversion programs that allow people the opportunity to avoid a permanent conviction and incarceration.
I am a graduate of the UT School of Law and the LBJ School of Public Affairs, I have practiced criminal law for fourteen years, I teach criminal law, and I am working on my Ph.D. in criminal justice.

I believe in hard work, honesty, integrity, fairness, and justice. We need judges that are competent, caring, and fair. As your judge, I will prioritize fairness, follow the law, and make sure that both sides get to tell their story. Throughout my career, I have worked to protect the rights of the accused, to make sure that victims are heard, and to ensure that everyone is treated with fairness.

Our local criminal justice system affects everyone. From my experiences with people incarcerated and formerly incarcerated, one of the major criticisms is that the judge didn’t really care to learn more about them as people, including the trauma they experienced that brought them to the criminal justice system. It’s important to hear about a person’s life and how they got to where they are today.

I will make sure that the criminal justice system remains fair to all involved, regardless of a person’s background. Every single person that steps into the courtroom must be treated fairly, with respect, and with dignity. The prosecution and defense are both entitled to a fair process in the criminal justice system, and I will make sure that happens in every single case assigned to my courtroom.

I think criminal justice reforms like expanding diversion programs to include more people, especially youthful offenders, supporting measures to offer more treatment options and rehabilitation services to people living with substance use and mental health issues, and supporting programs to help people find jobs, continue their education, and provide for their families are good for Travis County.

races.raceName: Judge, County Court at Law No. 1
Judge, County Court at Law No. 2
Judge, County Court at Law No. 3
Judge, County Court at Law No. 4

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: Court 4 is our Domestic Violence Court. I have 23 years of domestic violence experience, which includes leading the Travis County Family Violence Unit and Protective Order Division for over a decade[.]

For a DV court, experience matters above all else. As the current judge, I make risk assessments multiple times a day. I know when it’s fair to take guns away and I know when treatment and rehabilitation is the right answer. Without real DV experience, you can’t understand the complex nuances and dynamics of these cases, which means you can’t truly be fair to both defendants and alleged victims.

You or someone you know has likely dealt with DV. It is an epidemic that impacts us all. In 2020, 228 Texans were murdered by their intimate partner, almost 70 percent were killed with a firearm. I am proud, however, that in 2020, Travis County had the lowest DV homicide rate of any major urban county in TX. That is due in part to the work being done in this court and why I am seeking re-election.

I ensure that finances are never an impediment for any person in my court. I waive costs for counseling so people can get help to break the cycle of violence. I never revoke anyone due to their inability to pay probation fees. And as the first and only elected South Asian judge in Travis County history, I bring a previously missing perspective needed for equal representation in our court system.

When I took the bench in Nov 2019, almost 400 cases were on the jury docket. I devised a strategy to reduce that backlog. I revised policies and procedures to reduce delays and unnecessary resets, I added multiple trial settings a week, and I added a jury conference docket to facilitate negotiations between the State and the defense. As a result, the backlog has been reduced by 30% despite COVID.
I’ve practiced 18 years as a defense attorney, representing neighbors from all walks of life. I have hands on community experience as Chair of the Sobering Center and as a mentor with Hispanic youth.

A judge must have the strength to hold the system accountable—ensuring defense attorneys & prosecutors are doing their jobs & representing their clients. I have called out prosecutors when they have overstepped & defense attorneys when they need to step it up. I have also offered innovative solutions that respect survivors & help the accused bring stability & a positive future to their lives.

This is the family violence court & for 22 years this court has NOT had a diversion program. I will work with the community to create a diversion program—bring in social workers to help address substance use issues, school leaders & unions to help to establish job skills, & community orgs & non-profits to get to the root cause of problems rather than throwing someone in jail & calling it a day.

Equal access to justice requires systemic change. I will continue to advocate for diversion programs as an alternative to jail, support non-profits that promote pro bono work, as well as bias training, trauma informed practices, and cultural competency. As Judge, I will break down barriers to achieve equal access to justice.

Our criminal justice system is broken. Having a designated family violence court was a step to address underlying issues, but the current prosecutor-only mindset adds to the over incarceration problem. The danger is not just a backlog but a revolving door. My work with the Sobering Center shows we can protect children, survivors, & families and keep the focus on healthy, safe, & productive lives.

races.raceName: Judge, County Court at Law No. 5

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I am the only candidate who has judicial, family and criminal law experience. For 22 years, I represented indigent clients with a mental illness or substance abuse issues, all felonies & misdemeanors.

I view misdemeanor court as Opportunity Court. Thus, being fair involves improving the lives of people who I represent and who appear before me as a judge. Here is our opportunity to help treat the underlying issue bringing you into the criminal justice system in the first place. Doing so causes recidivism, i.e. the revolving door inherent in our criminal justice system, to be greatly reduced.

Ensuring that defendants are identified & provided with appropriate services will lead to an individual & to a household that is better off. Doing so strengthens our community as a whole. The collateral consequences of our criminal justice system have wide ranging impacts: loss of jobs, kids in foster care, loss of housing -this is too harsh. In my court, the American dream will still be possible

I want to expand what justice looks like here in Austin. I want communities of color to feel safe. I am seeking a seat at the table as we reimagine criminal justice because African Americans are disproportionately represented, accounting for only 7% of our Travis County population, but more than 33% of all misdemeanors filed & there has not been a black judge at this level in more than 20 years.

To address any backlog I would not give reset dates that are months away – short delays will still be possible for substantial reasons, urge prosecutors to turn over legally required evidence to the defense more quickly and work to place cases on a diversion track, especially for first-time offenders and those cases that involve substance abuse, poverty or mental illness as an underlying issue.
20-year criminal defense attorney focused on reforming the justice system to create a level playing field for all. Daughter of immigrants and former Democratic precinct chair.

As an attorney, my passion is to help others live more peaceful and fulfilling lives. Part of my job is knowing my client’s story and presenting their circumstances to ensure a fair outcome. I plan to introduce more compassion into the criminal justice system to begin creating a better future for every person in our community.

The county courts at law only hear misdemeanor cases, which are mainly low-level offenses. As a result, judges have the opportunity to promote restorative justice and treatment based solutions to help people. I want to expand the existing mental health docket to include trauma informed care and additional resources to assist with substance use.

As the daughter of immigrants, I have seen the negative impact the criminal justice system can have on families like mine. Through my lived experiences, I believe every person must be treated with respect and fairness to ensure justice. As an attorney, I often represent people with limited financial resources for free because every person deserves access to the justice system.

Through COVID-19, the court system has adopted technological innovations that have made courts more effective. These solutions will allow for a greater resolution of cases, thereby addressing any existing backlog of cases. I will work with community stakeholders to research additional solutions that will increase access to the court system while protecting an individual’s constitutional rights[.]

races.raceName: Judge, County Court at Law No. 6

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I’ve studied criminology for 33 years; I also majored in it at SHSU, and have practiced it as a criminal defense attorney for 17 years. My volunteer work has focused on helping young people achieve.

Empathy - towards both the accused and the complaining witness (if any) in each case. I’ve personally been a victim of multiple felony crimes and can identify with the need for the culpable perpetrator to make a sacrifice and appropriate restitution. However, the recompense must be proportional to the harm, and the accused’s personal challenges considered in order to achieve fair justice.

Travis Co. has approximately 1400 young people (17-21 yoa) charged with misdemeanors, currently. If convicted, their lives will be hampered, especially in a county like ours with such a competitive job market. Court 6’s Project Engage helps this population of accused people earn a dismissal and a clean record, improving our community. I would advocate for increased funding of this program.

As a criminal defense attorney for nearly two decades, I’ve seen the most disparity in administration of justice when it comes to bonding and probation revocations, where accused or probated persons with more money sometimes get better treatment. As an attorney who’s represented mostly indigent and mentally challenged clients, it’s extremely important to me that this does not continue to happen.

A judge cannot summarily dispose of cases; that is under the County Attorney’s authority, regarding misdemeanors. Depending on the backlog, I would hold extra dockets and two trials per week, assuming court administration and the clerk could comply with that schedule. I would continue virtual attorney conference dockets so that cases can be worked out, without the need for physical appearance.
Experienced trial attorney, lifelong Democrat, & daughter of immigrants. Former Legal Aid attorney & dedicated public servant. If elected, I would be the first openly gay Latina to serve this court.

Judicial courage is the most critical quality to possess for the fair administration of justice. This requires judges to address power imbalances and bias in the courtroom to ensure equality for all. As a former Legal Aid attorney, I understand the disproportionate impacts of the legal system. Today, I lead trainings based on inclusivity, equity, & anti-bias practices to address these inequities.

County Court at Law #6 is important to our community because it leads Project Engage, a program that helps youth impacted by the justice system. I have over 15 years of experience of mentoring historically marginalized students. I plan on using that experience to build holistic support for Project Engage through community mentorship, job training, education support, and trauma-informed services.

We must implement trauma-informed practices and cultural competence to tear down systemic barriers to justice. I will use a trauma-informed approach and culturally competent processes to increase equal access to justice. I will also advocate for accessibility, language access, LGBTQ inclusive language, and increased access to mental health and substance use services to address mass incarceration.

I will continue to use evolving legal technology to make court procedures more efficient and accessible. By using virtual pre-trial settings, we increase access to the courtroom by tearing down barriers to justice such as transportation issues, work conflicts, and childcare conflicts. I will also advocate for Emergency Response Dockets to manage and resolve the longest outstanding criminal cases.

races.raceName: Judge, County Court at Law No. 7

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What are the top three countywide issues you would like to address over your next term, should you be elected?
How will you ensure purposeful growth and development to improve living and business conditions in the county?
How will you improve affordability and reduce the number of people who are unhoused?
How will you address current and future transportation needs in the county?

positions.position: I am a civil rights leader, community organizer, former Grassroots Leadership director, and a new father who has advanced criminal justice and immigration reforms at local, state, and national levels.

Housing and human infrastructure: Tackling the affordability crisis with a County housing plan and investments in child-care and rental assistance
Alternatives to new jails: Rejecting the County’s $600 million plan for new jails and building mental health and substance use treatment facilities instead
Travis County for all: A Travis County that works for all of us, not just the rich and powerful

Travis County should collaboratively develop a Regional Housing and Transportation Plan – instead of siloed plans – that incorporates climate responsibility, conservation, water quality, flooding, affordable housing and transportation, and Vision Zero through equitable planning processes. I oppose giving billionaires tax breaks, including the $14 million in tax breaks given to Tesla.

Housing affordability is a community-wide crisis, requiring housing stabilization and new affordable opportunities. Our plan establishes a new County Housing Director position tasked with collaborating with advocates and developing a data-driven, county-wide housing plan that is focused on housing stabilization and affordability, accountability and transparency, and urgently housing the unhoused.

County transportation decisions can improve livability, health, and affordability for all residents, in unincorporated areas and cities. I will vigorously oppose freeway expansions – like I-35 – that divide communities, perpetuate inequality, and contribute to global heating. Travis County should adopt a Vision Zero goal to end traffic deaths in collaboration with cities, TxDOT, and CAMPO.
I’m a proven reformer with extensive community, small-business and non-profit experience, as well as seven years on the Travis County Commissioners Court, and three on the Austin City Council[.]

Our agreement with Tesla creates 5k+ jobs for the 50%+ of our adult population with less than a college degree, offering insurance, retirement, and a ladder out of dead-end jobs. We believe there will be many small businesses created in the ripple effect from our investment in Tesla. We directed $9M of federal COVID relief dollars to aid 224 small businesses, mostly women- and minority-owned.

We are buying down rents in over 11,000 affordable housing units, most being deeply affordable: 30-60% of median income. We’ve earmarked $110 million in federal funds for 900 units for people who are homeless. We’ve tasked Dr. Strakowski of Dell Medical School to recommend how to address the growing population of mentally-ill homeless persons.

As we approve more affordable rental units in the county, we require developers to provide shuttles to transit stops. We’re working with Capital Metro and CARTS to improve access to underserved areas. We’re reducing congestion by aggressive telecommuting, with almost half of county employees working from home. We’re pushing CAMPO & CTRMA to invest in making transit more effective.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What are the top three countywide issues you would like to address over your next term, should you be elected?
How will you ensure purposeful growth and development to improve living and business conditions in the county?
How will you improve affordability and reduce the number of people who are unhoused?
How will you address current and future transportation needs in the county?

positions.position: Lifelong resident of Precinct 4 Bachelor’s degree in Sociolog Master’s in Liberal Arts St. Ed’s Distinguished Alumna Graduated summa gum laude County employee since 1973 16 hours training per year

Complete homeless housing ($110 milllion)
Implement alternatives to incarceration
Implement mental health alternatives

Enforce subdivision regs with ingress and egress Provide safe roads to residents Address permanent flooding solutions Provide adequate affordable housing units to existing residents and newcomers Provide adequate Emergency Services and fire services to county residents

Participate with $110 million for 2000 homeless people Continue creating affordable units furor existing residents and newcomers (We have already created 11,000+ units in City of Austin and Travis County through our housing corporations)

County roads will be converted to urban roads with annexation. Will need upgrading for safety (FM812) New roads have Nike oaths and pedestrian sidewalks Annexations need to be done correctly to allow Cap Metro buses to transport people Hopefully Project Connect has plans to include residents of Precinct 4 CARTS’ contract with Cap Metro can keep county residents connected to other counties

I am a 10-year PMspecialist at AMD, an activist, and a 10-year DVISD Trustee. I know what it is like to face income inequality and have put my heart into advocacy for the last 10 years as a volunteer.

I want to address the disparities in healthcare that we see when comparing East to West Travis County. We need equitable infrastructure including clean water access, road maintenance, and truly affordable housing. The criminal justice system disproportionately impacts Black and Latino communities. I am a supporter of criminal justice reform that focuses on rehabilitation and not incarceration.

I will push for equity to play a key role in all county-wide budgeting and affordability decisions. We can accomplish purposeful growth by being strategic with development. For East Travis County there needs to be some investment in infrastructure to make it easier for developers to build much-needed hospitals, grocery stores, and other businesses that improve the quality of life.

I will support strategic plans and policies that provide investments in new low-income housing construction throughout Travis County. I will work with HATC as well as ask staff to work on programs and with partners to help those experiencing homelessness, prevent homelessness and reduce displacement using federal relief funds, grants, and other financial means that improve quality of life.

I will support strategic plans and policies that provide investments in transportation for east and west corridors. I will be a strong, vocal advocate for Travis County by being involved with all transportation-related groups such as Capital Metro, CAMPO, and the Central Texas Regional Mobility Authority to overcome years of exclusion of east to west routes.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I litigated in federal courts-civil rights for the plaintiff. Mediator. I clerked for Crt Crim Appeals, Hearings officer, City Austin Municipal Judge, incumbent Justice of Peace here past 11 years.

Knowledge of the law, compassion. Judges should dispense decisions within the confines of the law. Exercise discretion where possible & have the courage to go out on limb for justice sake. I will regularly order community service in the form of school based tutoring as opposed to the fine in the truancy cases when indigency proven. Magistrate duties when asked to. Adjust community service.

Justice of Peace is 1st contact w/courts for most & they will be unrepresented. Access both procedurally and economically are important. We provide resource literature for all areas of lawsuits as well as procedural info as allowed by law. Access to a computer remains in lobby. I give everyone reasonably ample time to present their side of the dispute. Keep website updated with information.

Give info on how to file or answer their lawsuit. Info on deadlines is given every eviction docket verbally as well as on the judgment; resources for attorneys & emergency housing is readily available. We keep updated. In extreme cases, I have continued a case to give the unrepresented party time to hire an attorney. If the “law” is problematical, go to legislature & testify. JP interprets law.

I have done that from very beginning. Triage to see what cases really still exist given passing of time; DWOP (dismiss for want of prosecution) any with statute of limitation issues; set in batches if necessary, groups of cases with similar issues to get resolved. Encourage mediation or resolution outside court.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
What quality is most critical for a judge to possess for fair administration of justice, and how have you demonstrated this quality?
Explain how this office is important to your constituents and provide details of your plans for improvement.
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
What steps would you take to address any backlog of cases?

positions.position: I serve as your current Justice of the Peace with almost two decades of experience as a Democratic leader. I’m the only attorney in the race and was named 2021’s Judge of the Year by JPs across Texas.

A judge should exemplify our progressive values. As JP, I’ve implemented criminal diversion programs so that people do not go to jail for non-violent offenses, and created the first program in the county that provides free lawyers to people who cannot afford a lawyer facing a traffic ticket or eviction case. I also implemented the first eviction protections in the state during the pandemic.

JP courts can protect our most vulnerable community members. In the past 5 years, as your JP, I have created a program that decriminalized marijuana, stood up to Greg Abbott on bad bail bond policy, and protected thousands of our most vulnerable residences from evictions during COVID and the winter freeze. I will continue to move this court in a progressive direction that represents our values.

As Texas’ first Asian American JP, our courts should represent the diversity of our community. As the son of immigrants, I have the perspective to make our courts more accessible. I am a national leader in virtual court, which provides working families an opportunity to show up to court at their convenience. I fought against Greg Abbott’s executive order that required cash bail for jail release.

The pandemic has caused a backlog on certain jury trial cases that have to be tried in-person. As a lawyer and state leader on JP courts’ response to the pandemic, I am developing a process to begin holding jury trials every week in the summer. We are considering conducting them outside and implementing required safety precautions to solve the backlog.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
How would you manage the elections process to ensure safe and fair elections?
How would you educate voters on recent changes to election law and the voting process?
How would you encourage citizens to volunteer as poll workers and ensure they are fully trained?
What other issue do you consider most important and how would you address it?

positions.position: I have 15+ years of experience, including as a nonprofit executive for Planned Parenthood, as Travis County Democratic Party Chair, being a community advocate for equity, and working as a court clerk.

As County Clerk, I will work with the community to identify more polling locations that promote equitable access; expand voting hours to 10pm as legally allowed by state law; communicate clear, succinct information to voters about the voting process through various channels, including social media; and ensure adequate staffing for polling places, including more bilingual and multilingual workers.

To educate voters on changes to the voting process, I would implement a strategy to: leverage mass communications, including traditional and social media, with clear, succinct information about how to vote and what to expect when voting; engage community partners to conduct outreach to residents with info and demonstrations about the process; and provide extensive training for election workers.

To recruit a robust pool of election workers and ensure that they are well trained I would: allow scheduling flexibility to recruit volunteers beyond those who can commit to 16 hour shifts; promote the Student Election Worker program at area high schools; and develop a multimodal training program that allows for self-paced, live, virtual, and in-person trainings, and mock polling demonstrations.

The county clerk serves as the custodian of records for county court proceedings. I would work to complete the digitizing process of county court records, and ensure the systems integration, training and education for constituencies that need regular access to these systems to improve efficiency and access. The county clerk has a key role in ensuring the right to a speedy trial and a defense.
I have a Master of Public Policy (MPP) degree and have worked in leadership roles across the private, public, and nonprofit sectors in strategic planning, data analysis, and operations management.

My goal will be to increase trust in the electoral process while maximizing turnout and reducing lines. We can accomplish these goals through meeting voters where they are with transparency and accessibility – making election information more easily available online, increasing visibility of the Clerk’s office through community presentations, and expanding polling locations and hours of operation.

The County Clerk has the opportunity and responsibility to be the best source of voting information for all registered voters. I would launch an elections information mobile app, increase the Clerk’s social media presence, translate voting materials into languages as diverse as our electorate, and expand our community outreach to groups like seniors, students, and newly naturalized citizens.

As a former poll worker, I support expanding our county’s investment, community outreach, and mentorship opportunities for everyone serving at the polls (and it’s a paid position, not volunteer)! We must raise the poll worker wage to $15/hour, expand the Student Election Clerk program, and provide additional workshops and trainings on how to serve multilingual voters and voters with disabilities.

In addition to elections, the Clerk manages important data and administrative processes like real property transactions, marriage licenses, and court documents. Everyone interacting with the Clerk’s office should be able to obtain any document that they need quickly and conveniently, while also receiving information about upcoming elections dates, polling locations, and hours of operation.

issues.question: What training, experience, and characteristics qualify you for this position?
Explain why you would make a fair and impartial Justice of the Peace.
How will you improve the services of the Justice of the Peace?
How would you ensure that all individuals who enter your court receive equal access to justice?
How would you ensure landlords and tenants understand their rights regarding evictions and receive information on available resources?

positions.position: I’m a First Sergeant and senior military planner with Joint Task Force TX. Certified firefighter, twice elected to the school board. Bachelor’s degree-Human/Social services. Military law experience.

I have a well-documented record of including all voices and perspectives into the discussion as a school board member. I have formal training in Human Relations I/II, Social Psychology, Diversity, Suicide Awareness & Prevention, Sexual Assault Prevention & Awareness, Victim Advocacy & Bystander intervention. I am Master Resiliency Certified and Central Registry Board certified  family violence).

As the JP, I want to be more hands-on including next-of-kin/death notifications – something I have experience with. I want to create alternative pathways for first offenders, youth offenders, and those whose interaction with the legal system has been largely created or exacerbated by poverty. Let’s create “sentences” that include choices such as job training, apprenticeships, and online courses.

I devoted an entire semester of my degree program to studying equal access to justice. It begins with intentionally meeting each person where they are if we want to truly help them take ownership of their outcomes. A one size fits all approach to fines and punishment disproportionately impacts the poor and does not address root causes such as poverty or skills deficits. As JP, I will address this.

Connecting people with available resources to assist them in times of hardship as early as possible can prevent a situation from escalating to eviction. We must raise awareness of available community, county, state & federal programs. Then, let’s remove barriers to access to higher paying jobs that are a result of skills deficits, transportation challenges, or access to affordable childcare.
District Dir., Rep. John Bucy, coordinating food delivery program and constituent services. BA Sociology/ Public Health. Chair, Cedar Park Planning & Zoning Commission. Life-long Dem & community vol.

As Chair of the Cedar Park Planning & Zoning Commission, I’ve demonstrated an ability to distill complex information, hear both sides, & work toward fact-based decisions that are fair and impartial. My background in successfully helping people access government and community resources, crisis communications, and collaborative problem solving entails working with diverse backgrounds and viewpoints.

I will modernize the office by making services available electronically and paperless when possible. I will remove barriers to accessing the court, including instituting more lenient dress codes, ensuring resources and paperwork are available in multiple languages and online, and offering virtual court proceedings. I also will perform weddings for all those eligible, which is not currently done.

Many people come before justice courts without a lawyer. It’s critical to provide access to lawyers and legal resources for those who cannot afford them as even low level offenses and evictions can affect jobs, housing, and other basic needs. Similarly, I would divert low-level cannabis and traffic offenses to avoid convictions, connect people with preventative services, and reduce recidivism.

Landlord-tenant disputes can quickly become complex, especially for those representing themselves. Educating both parties around processes, expectations, and existing legal resources can ensure a level playing field and smoother process for litigants. I would send this information to litigants in advance of their case, put it on the court website, and hold educational town halls on JP services.
